COMMENT: Known for its ancient dam and variety of bird species including several migratory ones.
Features scenic dams like Bassi and Orai; habitat for panthers and wild boars.
Located at the confluence of the Chambal and Brahmani rivers; known for its rugged beauty.
Former hunting ground of the Maharajas of Kota; part of the Mukundara Hills landscape.
One of the largest protected areas in India; home to the endangered Great Indian Bustard.
Nestled in the Aravalli range; source of the Wakal and Mansi rivers; rich in floral diversity.
Surrounds the famous Jaisamand Lake; historical game reserve of the Mewar rulers.
Popular for its artificial lake and dense forest area near the capital city of Jaipur.
Part of the Chambal River ecosystem; significant for the conservation of crocodiles and gharials.
Acts as a critical buffer zone for the Ranthambore National Park; rugged terrain with diverse wildlife.
A compact sanctuary in Dholpur district; offers a tranquil habitat for local fauna.
Famous for the majestic Kumbalgarh Fort and its population of the Indian Wolf.
The only hill station sanctuary in Rajasthan; home to unique orchids and the sloth bear.
Provides an essential green lung for Jaipur; features a biological park with lions and tigers.
A unique tri-state riverine sanctuary dedicated to protecting the critically endangered Gharial.
Serves as a vital corridor for tigers moving between Ranthambore and Mukundara Hills.
A peaceful wetland sanctuary near Dholpur; attracts numerous migratory waterbirds in winter.
Located on a hilltop overlooking Udaipur; famously known as the backdrop to the Monsoon Palace.
Famous for being the first reserve to successfully relocate tigers; rich in Aravalli biodiversity.
Integral part of the Ranthambore tiger landscape; rugged hills and diverse carnivore species.
Named after the historical Shergarh Fort; known for its scenic riverine and forest landscape.
Only sanctuary in India where the Flying Squirrel can be spotted; rich teak and bamboo forests.
A unique grassland ecosystem in the Thar desert; famous for its large population of Blackbucks.
Spans across three districts in the Aravallis; offers a diverse habitat for leopards and sloth bears.
A picturesque sanctuary in Dholpur; once the favorite retreat of the royal family.
Located near Bikaner; a lush green oasis in the desert known for its lake and migratory birds.
A popular spot near Jodhpur for observing desert wildlife like foxes and monitor lizards.
